preqs: For students who commenced their LLB (Hons) course in 2015 or later:LAW1111; LAW1114; LAW1112; LAW1113; LAW2101; LAW2102; LAW2112; LAW2111For students who commenced their LLB course prior to 2015:LAW1100 or LAW1101 and LAW1102 or LAW1104; LAW3300 or LAW3301 and LAW3302

rules.ruleString: (Must have passed 2 (I/W) units in {LAW1102, LAW1104, LAW3302, LAW4332} or  Must have passed 6 (I/W) units in {LAW1112, LAW1113, LAW1114, LAW2102, LAW2111, LAW2112})
Must be enrolled in course owned by {50000567, 50000568}

description: This unit involves a critical examination of the general principles and the rules of evidence and the use of evidence law as a method of ensuring fair trials: theoretical perspectives - reliability, libertarian, disciplinary principles, evidentiary law reform; rules and principles governing the proof of facts in civil and criminal trials; relevance and admissibility; kinds of evidence; competence and compellability; privilege; examination of witnesses disposition and character similar fact evidence; options of the accused; hearsay and exceptions to the rule; res gestae; confessions and admissions; illegally obtained evidence; corroboration; identification; opinion evidence.
